facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 674 of 1957 was filed as an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 674 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 10, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in C. R. Application No. 1213 of 1953, arising out of the judgment and decree dated April 25, 1953, of the Assistant Judge, Thana, in C. A. No. 97 of 1952, against the judgment and decree dated January 31, 1952, of the Court of the Civil Judge, J. D. Kalyan, in Suit No. 153 of 1949.

facts.text: Bombay High Court delivered judgment and decree dated August 10, 1955 in C.R. Application No. 1213 of 1953 confirming order of ejectment.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 10, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in C. R. Application No. 1213 of 1953, arising out of the judgment and decree dated April 25, 1953, of the Assistant Judge, Thana, in C. A. No. 97 of 1952, against the judgment and decree dated January 31, 1952, of the Court of the Civil Judge, J. D. Kalyan, in Suit No. 153 of 1949.

facts.text: Assistant Judge, Thana delivered judgment and decree dated April 25, 1953 in C.A. No. 97 of 1952 reversing trial court and ordering ejectment.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated April 25, 1953, of the Assistant Judge, Thana, in C. A. No. 97 of 1952, against the judgment and decree dated January 31, 1952, of the Court of the Civil Judge, J. D. Kalyan, in Suit No. 153 of 1949. Purshottam Tricumdas, Rameshwar Nath and S. N. Andley, for the appellant.

facts.text: Civil Judge, J.D. Kalyan delivered judgment and decree dated January 31, 1952 in Suit No. 153 of 1949 dismissing ejectment but decreeing rent Rs.445.

anchor.surface_text: against the judgment and decree dated January 31, 1952, of the Court of the Civil Judge, J. D. Kalyan, in Suit No. 153 of 1949. Purshottam Tricumdas, Rameshwar Nath and S. N. Andley, for the appellant. J. Umrigar, Ratnaparkhi Anant Govind and W. P. Oka, for the respondent. 1959. February 16.

facts.text: Appellant was tenant for about 20 years in premises known as Fida Ali Villa in Kalyan.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay confirming the order of ejectment passed by the Assistant Judge, Thana. The tenant who was the defendant in the suit is the appellant and the landlord who was the plaintiff is the respondent. The facts giving rise to this litigation shortly stated are that the appellant was a tenant for about 20 years in the premises known as Fida Ali Villa in Kalyan.

facts.text: Respondent purchased Fida Ali Villa building.

anchor.surface_text: This building was purchased by the respondent who gave notice to the appellant to vacate, as he wanted to construct a new building on the site of the old building.

facts.text: Respondent gave notice to appellant to vacate Fida Ali Villa to construct new building.

anchor.surface_text: This building was purchased by the respondent who gave notice to the appellant to vacate, as he wanted to construct a new building on the site of the old building. The appellant agreed to vacate and the respondent let to him a portion of his new building which was not far from Fida Ali Villa .

facts.text: Appellant agreed to vacate Fida Ali Villa and was let a portion of respondent's new building nearby.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant agreed to vacate and the respondent let to him a portion of his new building which was not far from Fida Ali Villa . The appellant had four sub-tenants, three of them also shifted to the new premises which were let to the appellant by the respondent.

facts.text: Appellant had four sub-tenants in old premises; three shifted to new premises let to appellant; courts found they occupied same position qua appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had four sub-tenants, three of them also shifted to the new premises which were let to the appellant by the respondent. Although it was disputed, the courts below have found that they occupied the same position qua the appellant. The 4th, a Bohri, was fixed up by the respondent in some other place.

facts.text: Fourth sub-tenant (Bohri) was fixed up by respondent in some other place.

anchor.surface_text: The 4th, a Bohri, was fixed up by the respondent in some other place. There was some dispute as to the date when these new premises were let to the appellant, the appellant alleging that they were let on July 1, 1948, and the respondent that they were let on June 1, 1948.

facts.text: Dispute on date of letting new premises: appellant alleged July 1, 1948; respondent June 1, 1948; trial court found June 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: There was some dispute as to the date when these new premises were let to the appellant, the appellant alleging that they were let on July 1, 1948, and the respondent that they were let on June 1, 1948. The trial Court found that they were let on June 1, 1948.

facts.text: Lease terms contained in Marathi letter dated June 7, 1948 from respondent to appellant permitting sub-tenants same manner as in old chawl.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of the lease are contained in a document dated June 7,1948, which is a letter in Marathi written by the respondent to the appellant and contains the following terms as to sub-tenancy In the shops in the old chawl which are with you you have kept sub-tenants. We are permitting you to keep sub-tenants in the same manner, in this place also .

facts.text: Dispute on translation of lease term: plural or singular 'sub-tenant'; courts found no difference to principal argument.

anchor.surface_text: The parties were not agreed as to the correctness of the translation of this term. The submission of the appellant was that the word sub-tenant should be in the plural and of the respondent that it should be in the singular but whether it is in the singular or plural it does not make any difference to the principal argument advanced in this Court.

facts.text: Respondent gave notice dated January 3, 1949 to appellant to vacate for non-payment of rent and sub-letting.

anchor.surface_text: On January 3, 1949, the respondent gave notice to the defendant to vacate the premises on the ground of non-payment of rent and sub-letting which it was alleged had resulted in the termination of the tenancy.

facts.text: Respondent filed suit for ejectment on April 20, 1949 on grounds of non-payment of rent and sub-letting (Suit No. 153 of 1949).

anchor.surface_text: On April 20, 1949, the respondent brought a suit for ejectment on the ground of non-payment of rent and sub- letting of the premises.

facts.text: Appellant defended suit claiming right to sub-let under lease terms and deposited arrears of rent in court.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the appellant was that under the terms of the lease he had the right to sub- let the premises. As to the claim on the ground of non- payment of rent he deposited the arrears of rent in court.

facts.text: Trial court held sub-letting lawful despite s.15 of Bombay Act 57 of 1947, decreed Rs.445 rent, dismissed ejectment.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court held that subletting was lawful in spite of s. 15 of Bombay Hotel and Lodging Houses Rates Control Act, 1947  Bom. 57 of 1947 . He also held that the appellant did not occupy the premises on the same terms and conditions on which he occupied the old premises in Fida Ali Villa. He passed a decree for Rs. 445 on account of rent remaining due and dismissed the respondents suit for ejectment.

facts.text: Assistant Judge, Thana on appeal reversed trial court, held s.15 prohibits sub-letting, landlord entitled to evict under s.13(1)(e).

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Assistant Judge at Thana reversed the decree holding that s. 15 of the Act completely prohibited sub-letting and under s. 13 1  e  of the Act the landlord had the right to evict the tenant on account of sub-letting.

facts.text: Bombay High Court affirmed Assistant Judge's order of ejectment in revision.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then went in revision to the High Court of Bombay, but it affirmed the order of ejectment.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by KAPUR, J. on February 16, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. February 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay confirming the order of ejectment passed by the Assistant Judge, Thana.

facts.text: Courts below found new tenancy created by letter of June 7, 1948, not continuation of old tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: The courts below have held that the tenancy by the letter of June 7,1948, was a new tenancy and not a continuation of the old and that the sub-tenants were tenants of the appellant and not licensees of the respondent and in this Court no serious argument was addressed on these points.

facts.text: Courts below found sub-tenants were tenants of appellant, not licensees of respondent; no privity between respondent and sub-tenants.

anchor.surface_text: The previous tenancy was of a different building called  Fida Ali Villa which came to an end when the appellant vacated those premises and entered into a new agreement of lease in regard to the premises in dispute. There was no privity between the respondent and the sub-tenants of the appellant and they could not be termed his licensees.

facts.text: Appellant argued no new tenancy after Act came into force, so ss.13(1)(e) and 15 do not apply.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant urged that there was no new tenancy after the coming into force of the Act and therefore ss. 13 1  e  and 15 of the Act did not apply  2  that the tenant had not sub-let the premises to the sub-tenants and they were merely licensees of the landlord  3  that no new sub-tenancy had been created

facts.text: Appellant raised new ground of waiver of right under s.13(1)(e) for first time in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: He also raised a new ground which had not been raised in the courts below or in the grounds of appeal or in the statement of case in this Court, that the respondent had waived his right in regard to the prohibition against sub-tenancy and the provision in s. 13 1  e  was for the protection of his rights which he was entitled to waive.

holdings.text: The tenancy created by the letter dated June 7, 1948 was a new tenancy and not a continuation of the old tenancy; therefore sections 13(1)(e) and 15 of the Act apply.

anchor.surface_text: The courts below have held that the tenancy by the letter of June 7,1948, was a new tenancy and not a continuation of the old and that the sub-tenants were tenants of the appellant and not licensees of the respondent and in this Court no serious argument was addressed on these points. The previous tenancy was of a different building called  Fida Ali Villa which came to an end when the appellant vacated those premises and entered into a new agreement of lease in regard to the premises in dispute. There was no privity between the respondent and the sub-tenants of the appellant and they could not be termed his licensees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts found new tenancy based on vacation of old premises and new lease agreement; no privity with sub-tenants; no serious argument raised in Supreme Court; contentions rejected as without substance.

holdings.text: The sub-tenants occupied the same position qua the appellant as tenants and were not licensees of the respondent; there was no privity between respondent and sub-tenants.

anchor.surface_text: The courts below have held that the tenancy by the letter of June 7,1948, was a new tenancy and not a continuation of the old and that the sub-tenants were tenants of the appellant and not licensees of the respondent and in this Court no serious argument was addressed on these points. The previous tenancy was of a different building called  Fida Ali Villa which came to an end when the appellant vacated those premises and entered into a new agreement of lease in regard to the premises in dispute. There was no privity between the respondent and the sub-tenants of the appellant and they could not be termed his licensees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts found sub-tenants occupied same position qua appellant; no privity or licensee relationship with respondent.

holdings.text: Section 15 prohibits sub-letting notwithstanding anything contained in any law, including contracts; applies to agreements between landlord and tenant making such permission unenforceable.

anchor.surface_text: This section prohibits sub-letting and makes it un-lawful for a tenant to assign or to transfer his interest in the premises let to him. The non-obstante clause would mean that even if any other law allowed subletting, e. g., s. 108 of the Transfer of Property Act, the sub-letting would, because of s. 15, be unlawful. This would apply to contracts also as all contracts would fall under the provisions of the law relating to contracts, i. e., Contract Act. An agreement contrary to the provisions of that section  s. 15  would be unenforceable as being in contravention of the express provision of the Act which prohibits it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-obstante clause in s.15 overrides any law permitting sub-letting, including contractual terms; such agreements contrary to s.15 and unenforceable under s.23 Contract Act.

holdings.text: Section 13(1)(e) is subject to section 15 and the two sections must be read together.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents suit for ejectment was brought under s. 13 1  e  which provides Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act  but subject to the provisions of section 15 , a landlord shall be entitled to recover possession of any premises if the Court is satisfied  e  that the tenant has, since the coming into operation of this Act, sub-let the whole or part of the premises or assigned or transferred in any other manner his interest therein . It was contended that s. 13 1  e  had to be read separately and not in conjunction with s. 15 of the Act. The section itself makes it quite clear that it is subject to the provision of s. 15 and the two sections must therefore be read together.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit language in s.13(1)(e) states it is subject to s.15; sections to be read in conjunction.

holdings.text: Agreement permitting sub-letting is void under s.15 of the Act and s.23 of the Contract Act; court will not enforce it.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant pleaded that under the agreement between him and the respondent he was entitled to sub-let the premises. Such an agreement, in our opinion is void because of the provisions of s. 15 of the Act and s. 23 of the Contract Act and enforcement of the agreement would produce the very result which the law seeks to guard against and to prevent and by sustaining the plea of the appellant the Court would be enforcing an agreement which is prohibited and made illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement contravenes prohibitory effect of s.15; enforcement would defeat legislative purpose; void under Contract Act.

holdings.text: Maxim in pari delicto does not apply to bar eviction under s.13(1)(e); landlord enforces statutory remedy, not illegal contract.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant relied on the maxim in pari delicto potior est conditio possidentis to support his plea that the respondent could not enforce his right under s. 13  1  e . But this maxim must not be understood as meaning that where a transaction is vitiated by illegality the person left in possession of goods after its completion is always and of necessity entitled to keep them. [...] There is thus a manifest distinction between this case where the plaintiff asked the Court to afford him a remedy against one who by contravening s. 15 of the Act has made himself liable to eviction and those cases where the Court was called upon to assist the plaintiff in enforcing an agreement the object of which was to do an illegal act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Landlord seeks statutory eviction right arising from violation of s.15, not enforcement of agreement; court enforces statute, not contract; distinction from cases enforcing illegal transactions.

holdings.text: Plea of waiver not maintainable as not raised in lower courts; waiver of s.15 prohibition invalid as against public policy.

anchor.surface_text: He also raised a new ground which had not been raised in the courts below or in the grounds of appeal or in the statement of case in this Court, that the respondent had waived his right in regard to the prohibition against sub-tenancy and the provision in s. 13 1  e  was for the protection of his rights which he was entitled to waive. [...] Waiver is not a pure question of law but it is a mixed question of law and fact. This plea was neither raised nor considered by the courts below and therefore ought not to be allowed to be taken at this stage of the proceedings. [...] In our opinion s. 15 of the Act is based on public policy [...] the plea of waiver cannot be raised because as a result of giving effect to that plea the Court would be enforcing an illegal agreement and thus contravene the statutory provisions of s. 15 based on public policy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: New plea involving mixed question of fact/law not raised below; s.15 on public policy grounds cannot be waived; enforcement would validate illegal agreement contrary to statute.

anchor.surface_text: The courts below have held that the tenancy by the letter of June 7,1948, was a new tenancy and not a continuation of the old and that the sub-tenants were tenants of the appellant and not licensees of the respondent and in this Court no serious argument was addressed on these points. The previous tenancy was of a different building called  Fida Ali Villa which came to an end when the appellant vacated those premises and entered into a new agreement of lease in regard to the premises in dispute. There was no privity between the respondent and the sub-tenants of the appellant and they could not be termed his licensees.
Thus the plea of waiver is unsustainable.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 on sub-tenants as tenants addresses issue i2 on sub-letting vs licensees

anchor.surface_text: The courts below have held that the tenancy by the letter of June 7,1948, was a new tenancy and not a continuation of the old and that the sub-tenants were tenants of the appellant and not licensees of the respondent and in this Court no serious argument was addressed on these points. anchor.surface_text: This section prohibits sub-letting and makes it un-lawful for a tenant to assign or to transfer his interest in the premises let to him. The non-obstante clause would mean that even if any other law allowed subletting, e. g., s. 108 of the Transfer of Property Act, the sub-letting would, because of s. 15, be unlawful. This would apply to contracts also as all contracts would fall under the provisions of the law relating to contracts, i. e., Contract Act. An agreement contrary to the provisions of that section  s. 15  would be unenforceable as being in contravention of the express provision of the Act which prohibits it.
Thus the plea of waiver is unsustainable.

It was contended that s. 13 1  e  had to be read separately and not in conjunction with s. 15 of the Act. The section itself makes it quite clear that it is subject to the provision of s. 15 and the two sections must therefore be read together.
